channel.title: Administrator password "recovery" (Win7homePremium)
channel.description:
I've pretty much tried almost every method of trying to gain access to the original admin account (or at the very least the password of this account) to my computer. This is because the admin of the computer deleted my account (which was not encrypted at the time due to my own stupidity). It seems when i try the backtrack linux method it doesn't work. Here is the problem with my backtrack linux method of hacking the administrator password.
(I boot to backtrack linux and enable default text mode, this version happens to be 5) as soon as the console appears i type the following "mkdir /mnt/sda1" "mount -t ntfs /dev/sda1 /mnt/sda1" "cd /mnt/sda1 /Windows/System32/config samdump2 SYSTEM SAM > /root/list" "cat /root/list | grep Administrator" (this next line of code is where the problem is, i have no idea if im typing this right or not due to my begginer knowledge) "/root/adminpassword/" (when i skip the above this next line actually does work) "cd /pentest/passwords/jtr/" (finally i type in this line of code and recieve a different error than the one stated above, saying that the directory doesnt exist) "./(my admin account) -f :NT /root/adminpassword"
Then after this method i try to use both backtrack and ophcrack the instructions to this can be seen [url=http://www.breakthesecurity.com/2011/06/how-to-hack-windows-admin-password.html] here[/url] When i finally achieve this all i get is "there is no password" (im paraphrasing of course). Could this be due to an encryption the dominant admin set on the computer? Finally i try several windows executable files that do the same, ophcrack, rainbow tables, ect... all seem to have the same issue. Is there anything i can do to solve this problem? I already have an existing "new" admin account on the computer, however it is hidden with the registry and password encrypted, also there is no way to log in through the command prompt due to the existing admin disabling this for all the accounts. If only i had his knowledge -.- Any help would be great. SOURCES: [url=http://backtrack-linux.org][img]http://www.backtrack-linux.org/wp-content/gallery/bt5-wallpapers/thumbs/thumbs_Backtrack_5.jpg[/img][/url] [url=http://ophcrack.sourceforge.net][img]http://ophcrack.sourceforge.net/ophcrack.png[/img][/url] [url=http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/windows7/products/home][img]http://res1.windows.microsoft.com/resbox/en/Windows%207/main/8/b/8b3fd718-d8e4-4dde-ba86-f70087b33a58/8b3fd718-d8e4-4dde-ba86-f70087b33a58.jpg[/img][/url]

item.title: Administrator password "recovery" (Win7homePremium)
item.dc:creator: @rant rant
item.description:
@rant wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:9, topic:400122”][quote author=rant link=topic=497212.msg3636298#msg3636298 date=1308619378]

Just pop ophcrack into your drive, and make sure you boot your drive with the cd and ophcrack will work it’s magic.

read what i wrote. “I also used ophcrack” my administrator did something to where the password will not show
[/quote]

I believe bt should include a “samdump2” program that decrypts the admin password. Unless they modified Windows to use a non-conventional method of storing the passwords.

Here, look into this; It’s what I used: http://tools.question-defense.com/Cracking_Passwords_Guide.pdf[/quote] yeah i just found out my samdump system didn’t quite “agree” with my system lmao

Read full topic

item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

[quote=“rant, post:8, topic:400122”][quote author=`SJ_ link=topic=497212.msg3635912#msg3635912 date=1308598618]
Just pop ophcrack into your drive, and make sure you boot your drive with the cd and ophcrack will work it’s magic.
[/quote]
read what i wrote. “I also used ophcrack” my administrator did something to where the password will not show[/quote]

My bad, it worked for my sisters windows 7 laptop.

Read full topic

item.title: Administrator password "recovery" (Win7homePremium)
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“rant, post:8, topic:400122”][quote author=`SJ_ link=topic=497212.msg3635912#msg3635912 date=1308598618]
Just pop ophcrack into your drive, and make sure you boot your drive with the cd and ophcrack will work it’s magic.
[/quote]
read what i wrote. “I also used ophcrack” my administrator did something to where the password will not show[/quote]

I believe bt should include a “samdump2” program that decrypts the admin password. Unless they modified Windows to use a non-conventional method of storing the passwords.

Here, look into this; It’s what I used: http://tools.question-defense.com/Cracking_Passwords_Guide.pdf

Read full topic

item.title: Administrator password "recovery" (Win7homePremium)
item.dc:creator: @rant rant
item.description:
@rant wrote:

Andrew Ferguson:

Wait wait wait, are you trying to steal someone elses admin account like your parents or something? Or did someone hack you and take the admin account and changed the login?

The administrator’s account password is the objective, If i was hacked the admin would not have contacted me about the resources he found on my account XD

Read full topic

Wait wait wait, are you trying to steal someone elses admin account like your parents or something? Or did someone hack you and take the admin account and changed the login?

item.title: Administrator password "recovery" (Win7homePremium)
item.dc:creator: @rant rant
item.description:
@rant wrote:

T4_:

There’s online services that will ask your for the encrypted password and return the decrypted result via email.

Unfortunatley my e-mail is being monitored by the root admin, and i do not wish for any other outside source to gain the admin control password.

Andrew Ferguson:

Just start up your computer and put in the cd for windows 7, move all your needed files over to another drive in that screen and reinstall windows.

I am sure the admin would definatley find out about that XD

Read full topic

item.title: Administrator password "recovery" (Win7homePremium)
item.dc:creator: @rant rant
item.description:
@rant wrote:

I’ve pretty much tried almost every method of trying to gain access to the original admin account (or at the very least the password of this account) to my computer. This is because the admin of the computer deleted my account (which was not encrypted at the time due to my own stupidity). It seems when i try the backtrack linux method it doesn’t work. Here is the problem with my backtrack linux method of hacking the administrator password.

(I boot to backtrack linux and enable default text mode, this version happens to be 5) as soon as the console appears i type the following

“mkdir /mnt/sda1”
“mount -t ntfs /dev/sda1 /mnt/sda1”
“cd /mnt/sda1 /Windows/System32/config samdump2 SYSTEM SAM > /root/list”
“cat /root/list | grep Administrator”
(this next line of code is where the problem is, i have no idea if im typing this right or not due to my begginer knowledge)
“/root/adminpassword/”
(when i skip the above this next line actually does work)
“cd /pentest/passwords/jtr/”
(finally i type in this line of code and recieve a different error than the one stated above, saying that the directory doesnt exist)
“./(my admin account) -f :NT /root/adminpassword”

Then after this method i try to use both backtrack and ophcrack the instructions to this can be seen here
When i finally achieve this all i get is “there is no password” (im paraphrasing of course). Could this be due to an encryption the dominant admin set on the computer?

Finally i try several windows executable files that do the same, ophcrack, rainbow tables, ect… all seem to have the same issue. Is there anything i can do to solve this problem?

I already have an existing “new” admin account on the computer, however it is hidden with the registry and password encrypted, also there is no way to log in through the command prompt due to the existing admin disabling this for all the accounts. If only i had his knowledge -.- Any help would be great.

SOURCES:


Read full topic
